concept.title: Cross-Device Visitor Identification
concept.shortdesc: Cross-device visitor identification (also known as visitor stitching) allows the Marketing Cloud to recognize visitors across browsers and devices, counting them as a single visitor. This feature allows campaigns from one device, such as a mobile device, to receive credit from conversion events made from another device, such as a desktop.

conbody.p: This feature works by associating the visitor profiles across each device where a user is uniquely identified. After association, the visitor profile records are merged and visits from each device are considered to be from the same user.
For example, in the following scenario, the same visitor is counted three times:
a potential customer clicks a link in a marketing email and views your site for the first time:

Using this type of tracking requires defining the s.visitorID variable in your implementation, which can be defined using existing elements on your site (such as a login username). Cross-device visitor identification can associate each visitorID automatically assigned with the custom visitorID set. Meaning, the visitor information is retained even if the user does not login immediately.
conbody.note: This topic is intended for users already familiar with marketing reports and the implementation specific to their organization. If you are not familiar with your organization's implementation, seek help from a Supported User or the Implementation Guide.

section.title: Implementing Cross-Visitor Identification
section.p: To use cross-visitor identification, all of the following requirements must be met:

ul.li: Cross-device visitor identification must be enabled for the report suite.
Your implementation must have a method to identify visitors, such as a login or email.
The s.visitorID variable must be implemented on your site to retrieve that unique visitor ID.

ol.li:
Ask your organization's Supported User to contact Customer Care to enable the cross-device visitor identification.
Specify the report suite ID, as well as a development suite for testing.
Access your dev environment site and log in.
Open the DigitalPulse Debugger and verify that your visitorID is set to the unique visitor ID as configured by your organization.
Access your dev environment site from another browser or mobile device and log in with the same credentials.
Open the debugger and verify that the same visitorID is set.

section.p: The visitor IDs from both devices are now linked with your custom visitor ID. Any time you now access the site from either of these devices (logged in or not), they are treated as the same visitor.
For more information on visitor stitching, see:

li.xref: 15 for 15: A Stitch in Time Saves... Visitors

ul.li: Implementing cross-device visitor identification without having it enabled will not correctly process and report data. Each unique visitor ID is counted separately, inflating your visitor count.
If your unique visitor ID contains personal information (such as an email address), it is recommended to either hash it or use an internal unique ID to help protect privacy.

section.title: Connecting Users Across Devices
section.p: Cross-device visitor identification uses the visitor ID variable, s.visitorID, to associate a user across devices. When you provide a visitor ID variable with a hit, the system checks for any other visitor profiles that have a matching visitor ID. If one exists, the visitor profile that is already in the system is used from that point forward and the previous visitor profile is no longer used.

The visitor ID is typically set after authentication, or after a visitor performs some other action that enables you to uniquely identify them independently of the device that is used. We recommend creating a hash of the username or an internal ID that does not contain any personally identifiable information.

In the previous example, after the customer signs on from each device, they are all associated with the same user profile. If the visitor later signs out on a device, stitching continues to work since the visitor IDs that are stored in a cookie on each device are already associated with the same visitor profile. We recommend populating the s.visitorID variable whenever possible in case the visitor ID cookie is deleted.
